text: 12 years of hard work

can all boil down 
to just 47 seconds in the pool.

Heroes will be made

Every successful business

Today, moving from concept to reality 
is easier than ever before.
Join us as we travel around the world

and meet developers, architects, 
and innovators

on the AWS Cloud.
Welcome to 'This is My Architecture'.

I am here in Australia, 
at the Gold Coast Aquatic Center.
It's six in the morning,

and the Australian National swim team, 
known as The Dolphins,
are here training.
It's your turn to shine.

With their passionate 
and dedication to this sport,

it's no wonder they rank 
among the very best in the world.
But for the swimming coaches and analysts,

there's one aspect of swimming competition 
that takes more planning than the rest.
selecting their relay teams.

And Swimming Australia 
have an impressive new app for this.
Hi, Jess.

Would you mind telling me, 
why is it so hard to pick the relay teams?

Wouldn't you just pick 
the four fastest swimmers?
We definitely go for the fastest swimmers.

But there's all different orders

So we have to consider 
a lot of different variables in a relay

to make sure that yes, 
the four faster swimmers are in the race,

but also that they're swimming 
in the best order to maximize their skills.

What prompted you 
to consider adding more technology

Yeah, I'm really curious 
about always finding ways to improve

And bringing technology and data in,
it was going to give us greater insight.

Our performance analysts, 
when they're analyzing a race,

we look at things like start time,
time to 15,
time to change over.

So how long it takes

how quickly they can do a turn,

So how quickly do they swim

So all of that information

of thinking in what we were doing, really.

Easy.

We use AWS Glue

to load the data from sources

Okay, so once you have this competition

what happens next?
Why do you have three buckets there?

So the data that we receive

So we can work this data and store it

Okay, so I can see

is actually flowing 
through many components in the architecture.
How does that actually happen?

We use AWS Glue 
to do the conversion and transformation.

And we use Step Functions 
to orchestrate this data pipeline,

which gives us like a single place 
to monitor all data pipeline,

and we handle our failure and retry logic

Good, so the outcome

Correct.
So this data is being used in two places.
One is the Aurora database,
which is backing our web application,

and also for training 
the machine learning model,
we're using Athena.

And then we allowed the data scientists 
to use this data,

train the model

it gives us like the API endpoint.

which returns the best relay order,

and that data is returned 
back to the user interface.

When we're going into a competition,

we'll slow that down.

Sure, so we want to use machine learning

We want to predict the swim time

Using that information,

we want to predict what's the final standing

compared to other teams.

we want to suggest the optimal lineup

Yeah, so we actually

They're the expert.

The 2020 Summer Olympics, 
now the latest major sports cancellation
caused by the global COVID-19 pandemic.
So let's take a look ...

The pandemic had a huge impact 
on the world.

I want to speak with one of their coaches 
to hear how this impacted them specifically.
Hi, Simon.

when the Olympics 
were postponed by a year,
how did the application help you?

There wasn't a lot of meets going on 
at some stages throughout the world.

So we didn't have a lot of data 
on some of the athletes.
So I think where it really came in handy

was all of their Olympic trials, 
their selection periods,

because we were then able 
to capture that data,

familiarize ourselves 
with the opposition team a bit more,

and then get a feel 
at least from a data point of view

of where their strengths 
and weaknesses lay,
to help us choose our best case scenarios.

So how did the application help you 
during the games?

We had a new event, 
the four by one mixed medley,

you've got two males and two females, 
you swim them in any combination.

And if you're trying to physically work out 
best combinations

for each of the eight countries 
that may be in the final,

by the time you get through that, 
the Olympics can be over.

So we were able to get 
the best combinations on the other teams

and then try and work out, 
what team we had to swim in the heat
in order to make the final,

without over swimming 
our best swimmers all the time.

Simon, how are you using the app 
to benefit the athletes?
Okay, so we're able to better illustrate

what the best teams are doing 
with their really change over techniques,

and how much time they're giving up
with the combination of block times.

And block time is the time that it takes 
from the swimmer coming in touching the wall,

to the swimmer's toes 
taking over, leaving the block.

With that knowledge, we can build that 
into our daily training environment.
And we can give our athletes a target time.

One of the things that I've done 
with the women's 4x1 group was,

we aimed for .15,
and that was like a past mark.

And they would practice that skill
without distraction initially,

to the point 
where they were very familiar with it.

I was then able to load through distraction 
of various forms, noise,
ice-cold water pistols in their ear,

waving taser guns 
up and down for distraction,
and see where that skill level failed.

Because we can't replicate 
the pressure of the Olympics,

but if we can teach the skill 
of what is required to be successful at the Olympics,

well, then we produce athletes that are given 
every possible chance to be successful.

That's great, Simon, 
thanks for sharing this with me.
My pleasure.
In sports, we're dealing with human beings,

and the computer and the machine 
won't know certain things

like if a swimmer was injured 
or a swimmer had got sick overnight.
So I might have to make a change there.

The other bit is 
there's a huge coaching piece to it.
We're really lucky in Australia

that our coaches are really have 
a great relay intelligence,

and they're quite strategic thinkers 
about their relay.
So a coach might come to me and say,
"I'm thinking about doing this tactically."

And I'll be able to put that scenario 
into the computer,

and we'll be able to play 
that scenario out for the coach.

It's really there 
as a supportive decision-making tool.

This all boils down to just wanting to support 
the swimmers and the coaches
to be the best that they can be
and try and help them find ways to do that.

At the end of the day, 
we're racing in the pool for the gold medals,
but we're also racing out of the pool

to always stay one step ahead 
of the other countries and nations

to make sure that our team 
are the best prepared that they can be
when they stand on the blocks.

I'd like to thank the Australian Dolphins 
for spending some time with me

and congratulate them 
on their outstanding 2020 Olympics.

In Tokyo, they won nine gold, 
three silver, eight bronze medals,

along with setting a new world record 
in the women's 4X100 meter freestyle relay.

There is no doubt 
that their spirit of innovation

is going to continue to propel them 
to even greater heights in the years to come.
